frameDefinitions: The words in this frame have to do with non-verbal communication.
An Agent, Situation or Entity has an influence on a Cognizer.
A Speaker addresses an Audience on a particular Topic.
The words in this frame describe motion involving a Vehicle and someone who controls it, the Driver.
A Speaker succeeds in getting an Addressee to believe or plan to execute the Content the Speaker has in mind.
The  Speaker expresses through language his wish to get the Addressee to act in some way that will help to bring about events or states described in the Content.
frameExamples: I <t>gestured</t> with my hand for him to come over.
These works had a profound effect and <t>influenced</t> her in the creation of a successful series capturing this sun-drenched region.
McNamara <t>addressed</t> congress on the state of affairs of the Department of Defense.
Tim <t>drove</t> his car all the way across North America.
At one point, Walter tries to <t>convince</t> his wife that he has had a story accepted by BBC Radio.
Mr Smithers always <t>encourages</t> the employees to stay late and work harder.
listRoleDefinitions: This is the sentient entity that communicates a Message non-verbally. It is normally expressed as an External Argument: <fex name='Communicator'>The teacher</fex> <t>gestured</t> us into the room.

This is the person to whom a non-verbal Message is communicated. It may be expressed as an NP Object or as a PP Complement: The teacher <t>gestured</t> <fex name='Addressee'>us</fex> into the room. The teacher <t>gestured</t> <fex name='Addressee'>to us</fex> to enter the room.

This is the content of non-verbal communication. It may be expressed as a <ment>that</ment>-clause Complement, a <ment>to</ment>-marked infinitive VP Complement, or a directional PP Complement: The teacher <t>gestured</t> <fex name='Message'>that it was time to leave</fex>. The teacher <t>gestured</t> to us <fex name='Message'>to enter the room</fex>. The teacher <t>gestured</t> us <fex name='Message'>into the room</fex>.
The <fen>Body_part</fen> is the specific body part of the <fen>Communicator</fen> which gestures.
The <fen>Indicated_entity</fen> is the entity which the <fen>Communicator</fen> is pointing out to the <fen>Addressee</fen> as meaningful.
When the gesturing occus.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the gesturing occurs.
The person who is influenced by the <fen>Situation</fen> or <fen>Entity</fen>.
A state of affairs--- which can be an event, state or conditions---that has an influence on the <fen>Cognizer</fen>.
A person or thing that has an influence on the <fen>Cognizer</fen>.
An Action that the <fen>Cognizer</fen> decides to carry out as a consequence of the influence of a <fen>Situation</fen> or <fen>Entity</fen>.
A <fen>Behavior</fen> that the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is engaged in independently but whose execution is subsequently influenced by the <fen>Situation</fen> or <fen>Entity</fen>.
An entity that stands metonymically for the actions and considerations that produced it.
The <fen>Agent</fen> acts to influence a <fen>Cognizer</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the Subjective_influencing event occurs.
The location in which one has influence.
The person or persons to whom the <fen>Speaker</fen> delivers their text.
The person who orally delivers a text about a <fen>Topic</fen> to a passive <fen>Audience</fen>.
What the text that the <fen>Speaker</fen> produces is about.
The <fen>Time</fen> describes when the speaking occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> describes the location where the speaking occurs.
This is the being, typically human, that controls the <fen>Vehicle</fen> as it moves.
This is the means of conveyance controlled by the <fen>Driver</fen>.  It may move in any way or medium.  With verbs, <fen>Vehicle</fen> is usually expressed as Object:

Any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion expresses the frame element <fen>Source</fen>. In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion.  With particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.

Any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen> expresses the frame element <fen>Path</fen>. This includes directional expressions and 'middle of path'' expressions, e.g.:

Any expression which tells where the moving object(s) ends up as a result of the motion expresses the frame element <fen>Goal</fen>. Some particles imply the existence of a <fen>Goal</fen> which is understood in the context of utterance.

This frame element is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path. Locative setting adjuncts of motion expressions may also be assigned this frame element.
The  <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Driver</fen> operates the <fen>Vehicle</fen>
The <fen>Place</fen> describes the location of a more specific motion (which has <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen>).
The person that the Speaker seeks to influence to act.
The person who intends through the use of language to get another person to act.
The wish for action on the <fen>Addressee</fen>'s part that the <fen>Speaker</fen> expresses.
A piece of written or spoken material that changes the mind of the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The general item or items that are the focus of the <fen>Content</fen> of the <fen>Speaker</fen>'s message.
When the <fen>Speaker</fen> suades the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The location where the Speaker suades the Addressee.
The wish for action on the Addressee's part that the Speaker expresses.
The person that the <fen>Speaker</fen> seeks to influence to act.
The person who intends through the use of language to get another person to act.
What the communication is about.
The written or spoken material that contains a message that potentially influences the <fen>Addressee</fen> towards the <fen>Content</fen>.
An entity which the <fen>Speaker</fen> believes should participate in the action.
The time at which the lobbying occurs.
The location where the <fen>Speaker</fen> attemtps susaion on an <fen>Addressee</fen>.
listRoleExamples: George Gilder would run with this idea later in writing the New Testament of supply-side economics that influenced <fex>Reagan</fex>.
<fex>The balmy temperatures</fex> inspired me to write a poem on the advent of spring.
<fex>The painting</fex> inspired me to take a risk and use the intense green for the sky.
What factors influenced Nixon <fex>to issue the doctrine</fex>?
Attention will also be paid to St. Paul , what influenced him <fex>in his thinking</fex> and what he wrote in his letters about sex, sexuality, men and women
Does anyone know what inspired <fex>this song</fex>?
Chavez has much influence <fex>in South America</fex>.
He lectured <fex>to the officers of the Scots Guard</fex>  in  1929.
<fex>You</fex> have to sermonize about the good times
He was the Director: he could lecture <fex>on whomever he liked</fex>.
<fex>Kim</fex> drove my old car cross-country.
I drove <fex>my car</fex> to Canada.
Kim drove <fex>out of town</fex>.
The bikers rode <fex>through the desert</fex>.
Kim drove <fex>into the parking lot</fex>.
The bikers rode <fex>all over the place</fex>.
<fex>Yesterday</fex>, Smithers paddled his boat across the lake and back
<fex>His speech</fex> convinced me to join the Peace Corps.
You haven't convinced me <fex>about that yet</fex>.
<fex>Chapter 6</fex> admonishes readers to quit smoking.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the Office of the Secretary of Defense
